title: 111_hr4526
content: The "Northern Mariana Islands College Access Act of 2010" aims to establish a program for college-bound residents to have more choices in higher education institutions, including public school grants. The "Northern Mariana Islands College Access Act of 2010" establishes grants for eligible institutions to cover the difference in tuition for in-state and out-of-state students, with a maximum of $15,000 per award year and $75,000 in total. Payments are prorated for students attending eligible institutions. If funds are insufficient to award grants to all eligible students, the Governor will reduce tuition payments first for students who haven't received funds before, then for all other eligible students. The Governor may adjust tuition and fee payments based on financial need and administrative burdens to avoid undue hardship. Further adjustments can be made based on income and need of eligible students. Eligible institution refers to a public four-year institution of higher education. The eligible institution must be a public four-year higher education institution located in a State, the District of Columbia, Puerto Rico, or Guam, eligible for student financial assistance programs under title IV of the Higher Education Act of 1965. The institution must also enter into an agreement with the Governor, using funds to supplement assistance for eligible students from the Northern Mariana Islands. An eligible student is defined as an individual meeting specified criteria. An eligible student from the Northern Mariana Islands must have been domiciled there for 12 consecutive months before starting college, graduated from a local secondary school after January 1, 2008, and begin undergraduate studies within three years. An eligible student must have graduated from a secondary school, be enrolled in a program leading to a recognized educational credential, and maintain satisfactory progress in their course of study. An eligible student must have graduated from a secondary school and be pursuing a program leading to a recognized educational credential. The term "institution of higher education" is defined in the Higher Education Act of 1965, the term "Governor" refers to the Governor of the Commonwealth of the Northern Mariana Islands, and the term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of Education. The Secretary of Education is defined as the Secretary in this Act. Institutions of higher education are not required to change admissions policies for eligible students. Students must apply for tuition payment with the institution. The Governor administers the program in consultation with the Secretary. The Governor, in consultation with eligible institutions, develops policies and procedures for the program under this section. A Memorandum of Agreement between the Governor and the Secretary outlines consultation and assistance for program administration. The Governor, in consultation with eligible institutions, develops policies and procedures for the program under this section. A Memorandum of Agreement between the Governor and the Secretary outlines consultation and assistance for program administration. The Governor shall report annually to Congress on the number of eligible students attending each institution, grant awards paid, any reductions in tuition payments, and progress in obtaining academic credentials. Additionally, a GAO report is required starting from the enactment date. The Comptroller General will monitor the program's impact on educational opportunities for eligible students, including difficulties in admission due to in-State preferences. They will also analyze the availability of institutions for Northern Mariana Islands students, considering caps on out-of-State enrollments. The institution will enroll students, address barriers like academic requirements, and report findings to Congress and the Governor. $10,000,000 is authorized for the Commonwealth of the Northern Mariana Islands annually until 2015, with additional funds as needed. This section will take effect regarding educational opportunities and admission preferences. Effective Date: This section will be in effect for payments starting from January 1, 2010. SEC. 4. GENERAL REQUIREMENTS. The Secretary of Education assigns an adviser to the Governor for program assistance. The Governor can use up to 5% of funds for administrative expenses. Programs under this Act are subject to Inspector General review. The Governor can accept donations for Act implementation. The Governor can adjust maximum student amounts for eligible students transferring between institutions under this Act.
